perturbation.original_text: To make generally available to securityholders of the Company as soon as practicable, but in any event not later than eighteen months after the effective date of the Registration Statement (as defined in Rule 158(c) under the Act), an earnings statement of the Company and its subsidiaries (which need not be audited) complying with Section 11(a) of the Act and the rules and regulations thereunder (including, at the option of the Company, Rule 158);
perturbation.changed_text: To make available to securityholders of the Company an earnings statement of the Company and its subsidiaries at its discretion;
perturbation.explanation: This removes the requirement to provide an earnings statement within a specific timeframe (18 months) and makes it discretionary, weakening investor rights. It also removes any reference to Section 11(a) of the Act and the rules and regulations thereunder (including, at the option of the Company, Rule 158), further reducing the company's obligation to adhere to specific accounting standards and compliance measures.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 11(a) of the Securities Act of 1933
perturbation.law_citation: 15 U.S. Code § 77k - Civil liabilities on account of false registration statement
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 11(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 imposes liability on issuers and other parties involved in the registration of securities if the registration statement contains material misstatements or omissions. By removing the specific requirement to make an earnings statement available within 18 months, the modified text reduces the company's obligation to comply with Section 11(a) which necessitates truthful and transparent financial reporting. This weakens investor protections afforded by the Securities Act.

perturbation.original_text: The Company agrees that any legal suit, action or proceeding against the Company brought by the Remarketing Agents or by any person, if any, who controls the Remarketing Agents within the meaning of Section 15 of the Act or Section 20 of the Exchange Act, arising out of or based upon this Remarketing Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby may be instituted in any state or Federal court in the Borough of Manhattan, The City of New York, New York, and, to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, waives any objection which it may now or hereafter have to the laying of venue of any such proceeding, and irrevocably submits to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of such courts in any suit, action or proceeding.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company agrees that any legal suit, action or proceeding against the Company brought by the Remarketing Agents arising out of or based upon this Remarketing Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby may be instituted in any court of the Company's choosing, and submits to the jurisdiction of such courts in any suit, action or proceeding.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'any state or Federal court in the Borough of Manhattan, The City of New York, New York' to 'any court of the Company's choosing,' and removing 'to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, waives any objection which it may now or hereafter have to the laying of venue of any such proceeding, and irrevocably submits to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of such courts in any suit, action or proceeding,' the amendment gives the company complete control over the venue of any legal proceedings, potentially forcing the Remarketing Agents into unfavorable or distant jurisdictions. This could violate the agents' rights under the Securities Exchange Act.
perturbation.law_citation: 15 U.S. Code § 78aa - Exclusive jurisdiction of offenses and suits
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 27 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 grants exclusive jurisdiction to federal district courts over violations of the Act and rules/regulations thereunder. While parties can consent to jurisdiction and venue, the modified text arguably attempts to manipulate this, potentially undermining the Remarketing Agents' ability to pursue claims in a fair and convenient forum as contemplated by the Act. The changes give undue power to MetLife by allowing it to choose a court that may not have proper jurisdiction or be convenient for the Remarketing Agents.

perturbation.original_text: The Company and each of the Remarketing Agents hereby irrevocably waives, to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, any and all right to trial by jury in any legal proceeding arising out of or relating to this Remarketing Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company waives any right to trial by jury in any legal proceeding arising out of or relating to this Remarketing Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby.
perturbation.explanation: The original text ensures that both the Company and Remarketing Agents waive their right to a jury trial. The modified text only explicitly states that the Company waives this right, implicitly leaving the Remarketing Agents' right to a jury trial intact. This could be problematic as it creates an imbalance in legal recourse, favoring the Remarketing Agents should a dispute arise. While the right to a jury trial can be waived, this right extends to both parties and cannot be unilaterally granted to one, especially without explicit mutual agreement. The change selectively benefits the Remarketing Agents and undermines the principle of mutual waiver.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Seventh Amendment to the United States Constitution
perturbation.law_explanation: The Seventh Amendment guarantees the right to a jury trial in civil cases. While this right can be waived, it must be a knowing and voluntary waiver by all parties involved. The modified text omits the Remarketing Agents' waiver, which could be interpreted as a denial of their right to waive or exercise their right to a jury trial, depending on their interpretation of the contract, leading to potential legal challenges. The original text clearly establishes mutual waiver, while the modified text creates ambiguity and potential conflict with the Seventh Amendment.
